channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: UK to Cut Planning Hurdles for Small Builders in Housing Push
item.description: The UK government said it would cut back planning hurdles faced by smaller housebuilders, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to deliver on his target of building 1.5 million new homes.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: An employee lays bricks on a new build house under construction on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Bacton, UK, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. More than half of Britons planning to buy a home in the next two years said their home-buying plans had either been brought forward or remained unchanged, according to a Bloomberg Intelligence survey.

item.title: Uruguay Holds Key Rate at 9.25%, Reinforces Tight Policy Stance
item.description: Uruguay’s central bank held its key interest rate at 9.25%, signaling that tight monetary policy will slow inflation to target over the next year.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

item.title: China Offers to Fund Colombia Projects If the US Blocks Loans
item.description: China could step in to finance infrastructure in Colombia and across Latin America if the US fulfills its threat to block funding, according to Beijing’s ambassador to Bogota.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Bogota, Colombia, on Sunday, July 3, 2022. Dozens of Venezuelan opposition figures, who turned Colombia into their unofficial headquarters in recent years, say the election of Gustavo Petro as Colombia's first leftist president puts them at risk, and they plan to leave. Photographer: Nathalia Angarita/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Seeks Approval to Raise $24 Billion in Foreign Loans
item.description: Nigeria’s President Bola Tinubu has requested approval from lawmakers to raise almost $24 billion for an external borrowing plan over the next two years to boost economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Bola Tinubu

item.title: Nagel Says Tariff-Driven Frontloading Helped Boost Germany at Start of Year
item.description: The upgrade of Germany’s first-quarter output numbers is primarily due to businesses and exporters attempting to get ahead of expected US tariffs, according to Bundesbank President Joachim Nagel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Joachim Nagel, president of the Deutsche Bundesbank, during a panel session to mark International's Women's Day 2025 at the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, March 7, 2025. European Central Bank officials are bracing for tough negotiations over whether to cut interest rates further or hold fire when they next set borrowing costs in April, according to people familiar with their thinking.

item.title: SNB’s Schlegel Warns Against Kneejerk Rate Moves on Negative Price Data
item.description: The Swiss National Bank doesn’t need to react to every monthly inflation reading even if it turns out to be negative, President Martin Schlegel said.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: Zambia to Remain in Default With Afreximbank Until Debt Reworked
item.description: Zambia will restructure its debt with regional lenders including the African Export-Import Bank and remain in default on those payments until the process is completed, Finance Minister Situmbeko Musokotwane said.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Situmbeko Musokotwane

item.title: IMF Warns UK to Keep Budget in Check or Risk Market Revolt
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves must stick to her fiscal rules and keep spending under control or risk a market backlash that undermines the government’s economic plans, the International Monetary Fund warned.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves delivers a speech during a reception for UK and EU businesses at Downing Street on May 19.

item.title: ECB Is Close to Reaching Its Inflation Target, Nagel Says
item.description: The European Central Bank is close to hitting its 2% inflation goal, but elevated uncertainty makes it impossible to predict future interest-rate moves and requires maximum flexibility, Governing Council member Joachim Nagel said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Jana Randow

item.title: Why UK Inflation Is So High and Tough to Bring Down
item.description: While a post-pandemic burst of inflation has abated across much of the developed world, Britain is still stuck with the highest price growth among big western economies.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Shoppers queue at a fruit and vegetable stall in Bexleyheath, Greater London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Southeast Asia Leaders Make a Veiled Jab at US Tariff Actions
item.description: Southeast Asian leaders called out unilateral trade actions in a joint statement late Tuesday, without specifically mentioning the US — the region’s largest export customer.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, left, and Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz, Malaysia's international trade and industry minister, during a news conference at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation, as the Asian nation ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.

item.title: US and EU Race for Trade Deal With Six Weeks Left Until Truce Expires
item.description: The European Union and the US signaled a willingness to end a stalemate and work toward a trade deal over the next six weeks, in the first major thaw in their frigid economic relations since President Donald Trump’s second term began in January.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Bloomberg News Editor News Editor Tony Czuczka shares what we know so far.

item.title: US Consumer Confidence Jumps Most in Four Years on Trade Truce
item.description: US consumer confidence rebounded sharply in May from a near five-year low as the outlook for the economy and labor market improved amid a truce on tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in the Diamond District of New York.

item.title: India Sees US Trade Deal as Key to Lowering External Risks
item.description: A successful trade deal with the US could help India mitigate external risks and boost its exports, the South Asian country said, as its government seeks to speed up talks and reach an interim agreement.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: Mundra Port in Gujarat, India.

item.title: Fed’s Barkin Says Firms on Hold Amid Elevated Uncertainty
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Tom Barkin said elevated uncertainty has led businesses to freeze hiring and hold off on future investment decisions.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: A store in San Francisco. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Hungary Holds Key Rate With Focus on Anchoring Inflation
item.description: Hungary’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged as expected, with policymakers focused on curbing still-high inflation expectations despite improving headline price data and a shrinking economy.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik, Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Mihaly Varga Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: Stronger Growth Seen For Africa as It Weathers Tariff Shock
item.description: African economic growth will accelerate this year, thanks to public investment in agriculture and energy infrastructure seen helping shield it from the global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Moses Mozart Dzawu

media:content.media:description: Tractors at an agricultural trade fair in Abidjan, on May 25.

item.title: Brazil Inflation Slows Down, Fueling Bets Key Rate Hikes Are Done
item.description: Brazil’s consumer prices rose less than forecast in early May, fueling bets that the central bank will halt its cycle of interest rate hikes while keeping its monetary policy restrictive going forward to tame inflation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati, Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Conjunto Nacional shopping center in Brasilia, Brazil.

item.title: The Rise in US Home Prices Slowed in March as Buyers Pulled Back
item.description: Home-price gains in the US slowed in March as listings climbed without a corresponding uptick in buyer demand.
item.dc:creator: Prashant Gopal

media:content.media:description: Homes in Hercules, California.

item.title: US Core Capital Goods Orders Decrease by Most Since October
item.description: Orders placed with US factories for business equipment declined in April by the most since October, suggesting a diminishing appetite to invest amid uncertainty about tariffs and tax policy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: Ramaphosa’s South African Building Spree Draws $13 Billion
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said his plan to turn the nation into a construction site and improve its economic performance has attracted a record of more than 238 billion rand ($13.3 billion) of investment.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A construction crane near Table Mountain in Cape Town, South Africa. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: SNB Removed Chevron From US Portfolio on Environmental Concerns
item.description: The Swiss National Bank sold its entire stake in oil producer Chevron Corp. because it now considers investments in the stock to breach its portfolio guidelines, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: A Chevron gas station in Emerville, California, US.

item.title: ECB Is Nearing 2% Inflation Goal, Three Years After Policy Pivot
item.description: I’m Craig Stirling, a senior editor in Frankfurt. Today we’re looking at prospects for euro-zone inflation. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: A projected illumination, to mark the 75th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, on the Grossmarkthalle building at the European Central Bank headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, May 9, 2025. In March, the ECB projected 0.9% growth this year, followed by 1.2% and 1.3% in 2026 and 2027. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: EU and US Kick Off Six-Week Sprint to Reach a Trade Deal
item.description: Over the next six weeks, a series of high-stakes talks are set to take place between Washington and Brussels after both sides agreed to an aggressive timeline to reach a deal that averts a transatlantic trade war.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: ECB’s Patsalides Sees Bigger Cut Unwarranted Now: Econostream
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Christodoulos Patsalides doesn’t see a bigger interest-rate reduction as needed at the moment, according to Econostream Media.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: A train travels along a railway bridge near the European Central Bank's (ECB) new headquarters, still under construction, left, in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, May 22, 2013. European leaders decided in June last year to hand powers to oversee European banks to the Frankfurt-based ECB, as part of a so-called banking union to break the link between governments' creditworthiness and commercial lenders. Photographer: Ralph Orlowski

item.title: Novo’s Sales Woes Herald Danish Export Slowdown, Watchdog Says
item.description: Denmark’s exports will grow clearly less than expected earlier, partly due to the setbacks Novo Nordisk A/S is facing in the US, the state’s fiscal watchdog forecast.
item.dc:creator: Christian Wienberg

item.title: Germany Ends Japan’s 34-Year Run as World’s Top Creditor Nation
item.description: Japan lost its position as the world’s largest creditor nation for the first time in 34 years, giving up the title to Germany despite posting a record amount of overseas assets.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: French Inflation Eases to Lowest Rate Since 2020 on Energy
item.description: France’s inflation rate dropped further below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, reaching a more than four-year low and adding to arguments that borrowing costs can be cut further.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Metz, France. Photographer: Nicolas Leblanc/Bloomberg

item.title: Thailand Clears Plan to Exit US Intellectual Property Watchlist
item.description: Thailand’s cabinet approved a new framework for enforcement of intellectual property rights as the Southeast Asian nation seeks to exit from a US watchlist ahead of tariff talks with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Naripthaphan Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Kashkari Favors Maintaining Fed Rates Until More Tariff Clarity
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari doubled down on his case for caution amid uncertainty caused by the trade war and the “paramount” need to defend inflation expectations.
item.dc:creator: Alister Bull, Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Neel Kashkari.
